title: From Departmental AI to an Operating System
narration: Most organizations have deployed AI across marketing, sales, and service separately. Each function optimizes its own pipeline. But customers don't experience departments — they experience a company. The gap between departmental AI and an operating system is the organizational intelligence layer that connects them.

title: Every Function Runs Its Own Pipeline
narration: Each function owns a piece of this pipeline. None of them see the whole thing.

title: Every Department Runs Fine. Together, They Don't.
narration: Marketing plans and publishes. Sales qualifies and closes. Service triages and resolves. Customer success monitors and expands. Each workflow is well-understood within its domain. The problem is between them — handoff failures, lost context, inconsistent customer experience.

title: More AI. Same Silos.
narration: SDR agents in sales. Chatbots in service. Content generators in marketing. Health-score models in customer success. Each agent accelerates its own function. None of them share context. The sales agent doesn't know about the open support ticket. The marketing agent keeps targeting a churning account.

title: The Customer Doesn't Experience Departments
narration: 87% of MQLs never convert. 70% of prospects are lost to inadequate follow-up. Then the deal closes — and service has no context on what was promised. A customer escalates while their CSM is unaware. Every cross-functional handoff is where revenue leaks.

title: This Is What the Front Office Actually Navigates
narration: Four departments. Fourteen agents. Sixteen knowledge sources. Eight cross-functional gates — 78 nodes and 175 connections. This complexity isn't accidental. It's what enterprise revenue actually looks like when you map it.

title: Shared Knowledge Connects Everything
narration: What your organization knows about customers, products, compliance, pricing, and territories becomes shared intelligence that feeds every agent across every function. A service agent that knows purchase history. A sales agent aware of open support cases. A marketing agent that suppresses at-risk accounts. The customer experiences one company, not four.

title: Human Judgment at the Boundaries
narration: Agents handle volume and velocity within departments. The boundaries require something different — approval, escalation, judgment. A qualified lead becoming a pipeline opportunity, a closed deal becoming a service engagement, a support pattern triggering proactive outreach. These gates are where human judgment matters most and where most organizations have the least structure.

title: Roles Shift from Execution to Orchestration
narration: RevOps moves from reporting to orchestrating cross-functional handoffs. Sales ops moves from CRM administration to pipeline intelligence. Marketing ops moves from campaign execution to demand architecture. The shift doesn't eliminate roles — it gives the CRO something new: a single view of how revenue flows across functions, and the ability to optimize it.

title: Build the Operating System, Then Let Agents Perform
narration: Map the domains. Build the knowledge graph. Connect the handoffs. Then let agents operate with shared context and governance at the gates that matter. Better models will keep arriving — your advantage isn't which model you deploy, but the organizational intelligence you give it to work with.
